title: The iPod turned 18 years old and everyone's getting nostalgic
text:
Apple’s original iPod turned 18 years old this week (Sipa/REX)

Long before the iPhone, there was the iPod.

The iconic white music gadget was bleeding edge at the time it was released, allowing you to carry up to 1,000 songs around with you wherever you went.

Before then, you were forced to carry a cassette deck or CD player and physical tapes or discs to listen to. Some people had MiniDisc players, but that’s another story.

Either way, the iPod turned 18 years old this week. To put that in context, Apple’s famous gadget is older than Billie Eilish.

The chunky device was unveiled by legendary Apple co-founder Steve Jobs who said in 2001 that ‘listening to music will never be the same again.’

Old school cool (Photo Courtesy of Apple Corp. via Getty Images)

It had a 5GB hard drive, was 0.75-inches thick and used the now-famous click wheel to scroll through a monochrome menu screen. You could load it up with 1,000 songs through a FireWire cable attached to your computer and even make your own playlists.

‘With iPod, Apple has invented a whole new category of digital music player that lets you put your entire music collection in your pocket and listen to it wherever you go,’ Jobs said.

Back in the day, this was the gadget to own (Photo by Justin Sullivan/Getty Images)

And now as it marks its 18th birthday, many have been getting nostalgic over the old gadget.

The @Apple #iPod turns 18 today. It revolutionized the music business, and it changed the way we interact with handheld technology (for the better, and worse). Here’s mine from release day in 2001. #iPodDay #iPod18 #Apple pic.twitter.com/XE0CzjFd8m — Joe Árvai (@DecisionLab) October 23, 2019

In honor of the eventful day October 23rd, 2001, I present my original 5 GB firewire 1st gen iPod in a beat up but complete packaging. It works beautifully still but needs a new headphone jack. Graceful, tactile physical click wheel and hefty weight. Love it. Happy birthday, iPod pic.twitter.com/6Om0dsIsob — Frank Orlando (@orlandomediaco) October 23, 2019

#donglelife iPod 1st Gen from 2001 hooked up to my MacBook. Firewire 400 -> 800 -> Thunderbolt 🤓 pic.twitter.com/5Je2OvmWqi — Tris (@trisvoid) October 21, 2019

Smartphones and tablets may have supplanted traditional music devices like the iPod, but the gadgets are becoming increasingly valuable as collector’s items.

Earlier this year, a mint condition original iPod was listed on eBay for a staggering $20,000 (£15,500). The launch price of the product back in 2001 was $399.

The listing explained: ‘I am a longtime Apple device collector, and this 5-Gigabyte iPod has been in my personal possession for almost two decades, kept in cool temperatures and away from sunlight. I guarantee that it has been completely unused and untouched inside its original packaging, along with its iconic headphones, charging accessories, and manuals.’

Steve Jobs would go on to reveal updated versions of the iPod (Photo by Kim Kulish/Corbis via Getty Images)

It’s not known how many original iPods are left, let alone factory sealed in their original condition. So, if you haven’t already, it may be worth checking the attic for any old gadgets you’ve got laying around up there.
description: The iPod is older than Billie Eilish
